newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany to meet EMU criteria, timetable - Kohl.
newsitem.headline: Germany to meet EMU criteria, timetable - Kohl.

text.p: German Chancellor Helmut Kohl said on Saturday that his country would fulfill the convergence criteria for European monetary union (EMU) and the European Union's single currency would be launched as planned in 1999.

Dismissing mounting doubts that a weak economy and record post-war unemployment would force government borrowing over the limits set by the Maastricht treaty, Kohl said Germany would meet its commitments to join EMU on time.
"We will stick to both the agreed start date and the convergence criteria," Kohl said at the opening of a tourism fair in Berlin.
He added that the euro must be a stable and strong and said the currency would become reality despite all forecasts to the contrary.
The chancellor was speaking after Germany's most senior government economic adviser said that Bonn would in all likelihood overshoot Maastricht's budget deficit and national debt criteria this year.

Herbert Hax, head of the independent "five wise men" economic advisory panel, told a newspaper that the euro's launch should be postponed until Germany and other European Union states managed to get their finances into proper shape.
